Comment: That's not what happened (well Louis fucking the finances with funding the American Revolutionary War is on point)  King wanted to raise taxes on the nobility, but the nobility refused. Even though that was literally the *only* way out of the crisis. The nobles simply believed it was their divine right to not be taxed, no matter how much the king and his finance ministers pleaded for it to happen. The lack of action compounded because the taxes *had* to fall on the poor. Louis XVI literally had a mental breakdown because of how stubborn the nobility was being. If anything they cut off their heads because they tried to flee France and failed.   The nobility though, especially the conservative nobility, they just ran the moment the people started getting rowdy, unless they were so severely out of touch or had too many assets in France. They also held up the early years of the revolution, and *that's* when people really got fed up. Came comin' 'round the Mountain then...

Comment: Fun fact:  'Trickle down economics' was once called the 'horse and sparrow theory.' The idea was that you overfeed the horses (the rich) with a large quantity of oats, so that when it passes through their digestive tracts, it leaves a lot of oats in their shit for the sparrows (everyone else) to eat.  Yep, the concept they cling to came from the metaphor of poor people eating out of rich people's shit.
